name: Home Page of Cameron Cairns
body:
### About Me
I'm a security conscious full stack web engineer who focuses on an applications usability, and user flow patterns. I enjoy all things Linux (on my second iteration of Arch Linux at the moment), am an avid reader of Ycombinator's Hacker News, and consider myself to be a veritable npr and community radio addict. I am currently providing volunteered support to some of the web resources of the radio station [I used to manage](http://www.kdvs.org), and looking for a full-time position where I can leverage my existing Python, Django, and Linux experience in a fast paced, quick turn around production environment with a strong engineering discipline to grow my skills.

### Current Projects
I am currently providing support for KDVS 90.3 FM's [fundraising](https://fundraiser.kdvs.org) and [library](https://library.kdvs.org) websites on a volunteer basis.

### Currently Reading
- Dark Pools
- A Random Walk Down Wall Street
- What Color is your Parachute?

### Technical Proficiency
#### Proficient
##### Languages:
- Python (2 Years)
- C (2 Years) 
- C++ (2 Years)
- HTML/CSS (2 Years)

##### Web Technologies:
- Django (2 Years)

##### Operating Systems:
- Linux (11 Years)
- Windows (11 Years)
- Windows Server (1 Year)
- Max OSX (1 Year)

#### Limited Experience Worth Mentioning (Less than one year)
PostgreSQL, Bash (Scripting), Javascript

### Development Environment
Arch Linux, Vim, Terminal (RXVT-Unicode with Fish-shell)

### Experience:
[ ASUCD Creative Media](https://creativemedia.ucdavis.edu/) - Davis, Ca  

Programmer, Linux Server Administrator (October 2014 - January 2016)

- Managed computing resources for KDVS 90.3 FM and other ASUCD units efficiently enough to be assigned additional web development responsibilities including porting an unmaintained PHP site to Django.
- Worked in a small team of 8 people which required me to be intimately involved with every detail of my projects since resources were spread too thin to allow for much specialization

[ASUCD KDVS 90.3 FM](http://www.kdvs.org) - Davis, Ca 

General Manager (May 2013 – May 2014)
- Managed 22 paid staff and over 100 active volunteers of a variety of ages and backgrounds, with a budget of $133,000 per annum
- Successfully negotiated an $8,000 budgetary increase at the end of my term to cover long term expenses and to reflect a $10,000 increase in fundraising revenue
- Coordinated a $120.000 project which resulted in a 30% increase in broadcast strength from 9 KW to 13 KW

Business Manager (June 2012 – June 2013)

- Experienced the departmentalization of services within a large organization
- Learned how to read and stay within a $100,000 budget
- Experience purchasing processes within large organizations

[UC Davis Student Housing](http://housing.ucdavis.edu/) - Davis, Ca

Resident Computing Advisor (April 2012 – December 2013)

- Improved customer service skills
- Gained insight on usage patterns of novice computer users
- Learned to work as a team with coworkers meeting for only one hour each week

###Projects:
####KDVS Library 
(June 2015 – February 2016)

Ported an existing website in production for 9 years written in PHP to Django, which required a complete rewrite due to the former site’s lack of maintenance. The KDVS Library website is a UX focused CRUD wrapper for the million plus object KDVS Library database, with an API for displaying info to the front page website KDVS.org.

####KDVS Fundraiser 
(October 2014 – May 2015)

Upgraded a production site which handles $50,000 in transactions per annum to be able to show privileged users information about different fundraising years. Required a major reworking of the controller to switch context between fundraising objects, and a minor change to the view to allow for this switch.

####KDVS 90.3 FM Yolo County Landfill Transmitter

(November 2013 - October 2014)
### More info
Thank you for taking the time to visit my website. 
For inquiries please contact me at: cameroncairns(at)gmail.com
note: Don't delete this file! It's used internally to help with page regeneration.
